awd_titl_txt: SBIR Phase I: A CPR-integrated airway and ventilator system that eliminates human operator variability
awd_abstract_narration:
The broader impact/commercial potential of this Small Business Innovation Research (SBIR) Phase I project is enabling automated cardiac resuscitation in emergency situations. Cardiopulmonary Resuscitation (CPR) is a manual process dependent on responder skills. Ventilation, the proper delivery of air into the patient’s airways, is the process during CPR that requires the most skill and, because it is manually accomplished, is the most variable - especially in high stress environments. The proposed automated system offers a convenient, reliable way of accessing the airway which automatically synchronizes ventilation with chest compressions to improve blood circulation during CPR. The system also introduces a defibrillation electrode in the airway tube to enable cardiac defibrillation at lower, safer voltages. 
 
This SBIR Phase I project develops a novel, automated system to provide convenient, reliable patient ventilation and synchronization of compressions. The project’s technical milestones are to demonstrate: (A) reduced operator variability during airway placement and improved oxygen supply in swine models compared to current solutions, (B) reliable detection of cardiac contractions from pressure changes measured in the airway, and (C) feasibility of electric defibrillation with lower energy in cadaver models. The technical challenges are to: account for variations in human anatomy and detect errors with insertion into the airway, account for chest compressions not detected by the system, and ensure electrical contact between the defibrillation electrode and the esophagus during cardiac defibrillation.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Technology, Innovation, and Partnerships

por.por_cntn:
CoLabs Medical, with the support of a Phase I National Science Foundation (NSF) grant, has made significant strides in the development of the Ventor System, an automated airway and ventilation system specifically designed for the treatment of cardiac arrest. This breakthrough has been achieved through rigorous testing and evaluation in both living animal and cadaver models.

 

The objectives of the NSF grant were to assess the performance and efficacy of the Ventor system in an in vivo animal model and a cadaveric model. The in vivo animal model evaluation was particularly important as it allowed for the examination of the Ventor System in a living, breathing organism, closely mimicking the conditions under which the system will be used in real life. This assessment provided valuable insights into the system's performance under the conditions of Cardiopulmonary Resuscitation (CPR).

 

The cadaveric model, on the other hand, offered an invaluable opportunity to evaluate the Ventor system in a controlled, non-living environment. This allowed the researchers to scrutinize every aspect of the device’s operation and performance in a setting that would not pose any risks to live patients. Additionally, it enabled the research team to study the system's ease of use in terms of setup, operation, and troubleshooting, as these factors are paramount in a real-world emergency scenario where time is of the essence.

 

The results from these evaluations painted a highly encouraging picture. The Ventor System emerged as a viable alternative for airway management and ventilation during CPR. The system's performance was assessed based on its ability to maintain the airway, its efficiency in ventilation, and its ability to integrate with the ongoing CPR procedures. In all these criteria, the Ventor system showed promising results, indicating that it could indeed be a potential game-changer in cardiac arrest treatment.

 

In terms of ease of use, the Ventor system stood out distinctly. Ease of use is an essential factor in medical emergencies where each second is crucial. The Ventor System was not only easy to set up but also simple to operate, allowing for quick adaptation and application even under stress. Its user-friendly interface and efficient design ensure that healthcare professionals can focus more on the patient's care rather than wrestling with complex equipment.

 

Comparing the Ventor system to other traditional methods, its automated nature makes it a more reliable option. While conventional airway management and ventilation methods require manual intervention and constant monitoring, the Ventor system, being automated, minimizes these requirements. This automation allows for more consistent and reliable airway management and ventilation during CPR, reducing the chances of human error and improving the overall effectiveness of the treatment.

 

The encouraging outcomes of the study give a green light to the Ventor system’s next set of testing. These results, however, are only the beginning of a series of rigorous assessments and improvements for the Ventor system. It is an ongoing process of refinement to ensure that the Ventor system can continue to perform at its peak during the most critical moments of patient care

 


Last Modified: 07/07/2023
Modified by: Clay Nolan
